awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Scalable Event Trend Analytics For Data Stream Inquiry
awd_abstract_narration:
Data streams have grown in unprecedented scale and velocity in recent years.  The real-time discovery of emerging event trends in data streams is essential for time-critical applications from computing infection spread patterns across major medical facilities to detecting frequent stock trends. This project overcomes the shortcomings of state-of-the-art systems and provides practical solutions for this important class of analytics.  The invention of transformative strategies to provide these Event Trend Analytics services is game changing. Event stream applications affecting our daily lives include health care and financial fraud.   The integration of this project's activities with the training of a future STEM workforce will occur within a new interdisciplinary degree program in Data Science. 

This project develops both a sound theoretical foundation and practical processing strategies that empower applications to pursue interactive event trend analysis with high responsiveness.  This project enables Kleene-closure based analytics in modern stream processing systems.  Scalable Event Trend Analytics allows applications to gain trend-related insights from high-velocity stream data. Project activities include:(a) expressive event trend modeling and matching semantics, (b) compact event trend encoding techniques, (c) optimizaton methodology for aggregation push-down into the Kleene closure computation avoiding expensive trend construction, (d) aggregation computation at multiple granularity levels, (e) principled foundation of correctness and completeness of the query processing paradigm, and (f) distributed and shared execution of trend analytics for scale-up.  Principles from database systems, such as query rewriting, optimization, execution sharing, and scalable cloud computing, are applied to this problem. Innovations include trend aggregation strategies that selectively skip expensive trend construction, and compression methods for aggregation state models. These methods will be validated for utility and effectiveness using real-world workloads in partnerships with industry collaborators in healthcare and financial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Data streams from network traffic to social media data streams have grown in scale and velocity. The real-time discovery of emerging event trends in data streams is essential for time-critical applications from computing infection spread patterns across major medical facilities, detecting frequent stock trends, to uncovering failures in distributed IoT systems. This project overcomes the shortcomings of state-of-the-art systems by providing practical solutions for this important class of analytics. This project has developed Event Trend Analytics services that infer relevant patterns from these event streams in real-time to make near instantaneous yet informed decisions crucial for these mission-critical applications. In particular, the resulting technology is a core enabler for applications affecting our daily lives include health care and financial fraud.

This project has developed a sound theoretical foundation and practical processing strategies that empower stakeholders across many critical applications to pursue interactive event trend analysis with high responsiveness. One important outcome of this project is effective execution strategies for complex event queries with Kleene closure. Such queries extract event sequences of arbitrary, statically unknown length, which we call event trends. Due to common event sub-sequences in event trends, the following problems arise with the state-of-the-art technologies:  either the responsiveness is delayed by repeated computations, or an exorbitant amount of memory is required to store partial results by state-of-the-art systems. Our solution instead compactly encodes event trend information using a graph-based data structure and detects trends in optimal response time given a limited memory. Scalable Event Trend Analytics allows stakeholders across many applications to gain trend-related insights from high-velocity stream data and thus allow for in-time reactions.

The second outcome is optimization methodology for aggregation push-down into the Kleene closure computation to avoid expensive trend construction. Our runtime executor incrementally updates aggregates while reducing both time and space complexity. Innovations include trend aggregation strategies that selectively skip expensive trend construction, and compression methods for aggregation state models. Further, our event processor supports efficient trend aggregation under a variety of rich event matching semantics by computing aggregates at multiple granularity levels from fine (per matched event), medium (per event type), to coarse (per pattern). This minimizes the number of incrementally maintained aggregates --  reducing both the time and space complexity.

The third innovation is the scalable shared execution strategies for a workload composed of many similar event pattern queries on huge data streams. Instead of processing each query separately, our system shares incremental trend aggregation tasks among queries in the workload. Given sharing is not always beneficial, our system features run-time sharing optimizer that determines and dynamically enables optimized sharing execution plans driven by a cost model that monitors the overhead incurred in shared expression updates.

The integration of this project's activities with the training of a future STEM workforce has taken place within the interdisciplinary degree program in Data Sciences. Numerous Women+ students at WPI at educational levels from BS, MS to Ph.D. students have pursued research on this NSF project in the area of event trend analytics. With Women a minority in Engineering and Computer Sciences, this contributes to the diversity in talent development needed to drive the future increasingly high-tech economy of the US and to help assure that Women+ and other minorities in computing have an opportunity to participate in this industry. As part of this project, we also offer professional development opportunities to our students to provide them opportunities to hone their communication and presentation skills while pitching their project and its impact to diverse stakeholders, including visitors at the annual WPI Graduate Research Innovation Exchange Day and to the Data Science Executive Advisory Board members from different industry sectors.

Students participating in this NSF project have served as lead ambassadors and organizers of the Women in Data Science Central Massachusetts @ WPI event, with WIDS a worldwide event distributed across over well 100+ sites across the country and the world. At WPI, we have turned this into an annual student-run symposium to give our leading students an opportunity to develop leadership skills, invite speakers and run the sessions. This networking symposium not only provides opportunities to Women+ students to learn about inspiring career opportunities from Women leaders in industry and academia, but they also develop a support network of like-minded Women that will support each other to become part of the talent pool critical for our digital information economy.
